text.b: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District

page.text: Stephen C. Smith, Executi ve Director
James C. Hadfi eld, Transportati on Planning Manager

text.i: The preparati on of this report has been fi nanced in part through grant[s] from the Federal Highway Administrati on and
Federal Transit Administrati on, U.S. Department of Transportati on, under the State Planning and Research Program,
Secti on 505 [or Metropolitan Planning Program, Secti on 104(f)] of Title 23, U.S. Code through Massachusett s Department
of Transportati on contract 69625. The contents of this report do not necessarily refl ect the oﬃ
cial views or policy of the U.S.
The Southeastern Massachusett s Metropolitan Planning Organizati on (SMMPO) through the Southeastern Regional Planning
and Economic Development District (SRPEDD) states its policy to uphold and assure full compliance with Title VI of the Civil
Rights Act of 1964, the Civil Rights Restorati on Act of 1987, Executi ve Order 13166 and related federal and state statutes and
regulati ons. Title VI prohibits discriminati on in federally assisted programs and requires that no person in the United States
of America shall, on the grounds of race, color, or nati onal origin, be excluded from parti cipati on in, be denied the benefi ts
of, or be otherwise subjected to discriminati on under any program or acti vity receiving federal assistance. Massachusett s law
also prohibits discriminati on based on race, color, and/or nati onal origin, and the SMMPO assures compliance with these
laws and related federal and state civil rights laws prohibiti ng discriminati on based on sex, age, and/or disability. Individuals
who feel they have been discriminated against in violati on of Title VI must fi le a complaint within 180 days with the SRPEDD
The SMMPO and SRPEDD also uphold the Massachusett s Public Accommodati on Law, M.G.L. c 272 §§92a, 98, 98a, and the
Governor’s Executi ve Order 526, secti on 4 which provide that access to programs, services and benefi ts be provided without
regard to religious creed, sexual orientati on, gender identi ty or expression, veteran’s status and/or ancestry, along with
the bases previously referenced. Public accommodati on concerns can be brought to SRPEDD’s Title VI / Nondiscriminati on
Specialist. Complaints must be fi led with the Massachusett s Commission Against Discriminati on (MCAD) within 300 days of
For informati on or to fi le a complaint under Title VI or the state Public Accommodati ons law, the contacts are as follows:
& Economic Development District One Ashburton Place, 6th Floor
Title VI / Nondiscriminati on Coordinator Boston, MA 02109
The SMMPO is equally committ ed to implementi ng federal Executi ve Order 12898, enti tled “Federal Acti ons to Address
Environmental Justi ce in Minority Populati ons and Low-Income Populati ons.” In this capacity, the SMMPO identi fi es and
addresses disproporti onately high and adverse human health or environmental eﬀ ects of its programs, policies, and acti viti es
on minority populati ons and low-income populati ons. The SMMPO carries out this responsibility by involving minority and
low income individuals in the transportati on process and considering their transportati on needs in the development and
review of the SMMPO’s transportati on plans, programs and projects.

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Evaluati on, New Bedford

page.text: Existi ng Conditi ons: Intersecti on Operati on
Existi ng Conditi ons: Bicycle and Pedestrian Accommodati

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Evaluati on, New Bedford

page.text: The Octopus intersecti on provides important connecti ons from downtown New
Bedford to Fairhaven and Dartmouth via Route 6, as well as to the north and
south ends of the city via Pleasant Street. It is the focal point of vehicle and
c for a busy downtown area. It conti nues to be known as a
problem area to many city residents and was oﬃ
cially identi fi ed as a congesti on
issue in the 2012 Regional Transportati on Plan.
Navigati ng this busy intersecti on in a vehicle or on foot can be confusing,
frustrati ng, and dangerous. Three pedestrian crashes have occurred here over
the past several years, with one crash resulti ng in a fatality. During the course of
the study, issues parti cular to this intersecti on were identi fi ed:
Safety and congesti on problems at the Route 6 westbound approach
c from the Route 18 oﬀ ramp att empti ng to cross two lanes
Route 6 westbound approach has a right-turn green arrow that works
in conjuncti on with a ‘No Turn On Red’ sign creati ng confusion for both
Vehicle queues on Pleasant Street between Hillman Street and the
Octopus are blocking access and egress to the city’s main fi re stati on;
Vehicle queues created by the closing of the New Bedford – Fairhaven
Bridge severely congests the intersecti on and contributes to the blocked
access and egress of the fi re stati on;
Pedestrian crashes, including a fatality, identi fi ed the poor placement of
crosswalks, inadequate crossing ti mes and an extended wait period for
People reluctant to use the pedestrian overpass due to its isolated
locati on away from the intersecti on, its steep grade over Route 6, and
concern for personal safety when crossing the bridge alone at night.
SRPEDD’s recommendati ons for this intersecti on are referred to as Alternati ve A
in the study. This alternati ve includes the following improvements:
Signal ti mings / Equipment – The opti mizati on of the signal ti mings which
would require the replacement of the existi ng traﬃ
would include separate concurrent pedestrian phases that would operate in
conjuncti on with each non-opposing signal phase and adequate pedestrian
crossing ti mes for each approach based on the crossing width.
Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
Pavement markings - The updati ng of all pavement markings at the intersecti on.
This would include re-striping the center lane on the Route 6 westbound
approach as a shared thru/left -turn lane with line extensions conti nuing
through the intersecti on and onto Sixth Street. It would also include pavement
markings on Pleasant Street north of the intersecti on and on Sixth street south
of the intersecti on in order to formalize two travel lanes on each of these legs
c through the intersecti on, as well as ‘yield’ pavement
markings at the northbound right approach and formal bicycle lanes.
Signage – This includes Stop signs, Yield signs, No Turn On Red signs, No Right
Turn signs, No Left Turn signs, Intersecti on Lane Control signs (depicti ng the new
confi gurati on at the westbound approach), and a Push Butt on For Walk sign for
pedestrians on the safe and proper use of pedestrians signals.
ADA compliant bicycle and pedestrian safety improvements - This includes
the installati on and upgrading of sidewalks, updated crosswalks, curb ramps
with detectable warning panels and signage and formal bicycle lanes. Some
geometric modifi cati ons to accommodate changes may be necessary.
Pedestrian overpass – This includes making the overpass more user-friendly by
removing surrounding shrubbery and providing bett er lighti ng.
Pedestrian educati on – This includes instructi onal pamphlets and posters,
especially for the residents of Melville Towers and the New Bedford Hotel on
pedestrian safety and the safe and proper use of the intersecti on.

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: The intersecti on of Pleasant Street, Kempton Street, Mill Street, Sixth Street,
and Route 6 in New Bedford is the focal point of vehicle and pedestrian traﬃ
for a busy downtown area. Although the origin is unclear, residents refer to this
locati on as the “Octopus” due to the numerous road segments that make up the
The Octopus is a gateway to the Central Business District of New Bedford
and connects it to all parts of the city as well as to the towns of Fairhaven
and Dartmouth. It conti nues to be known as a problem area to many city
cially identi fi ed as a congesti on issue in the 2012 Regional
Due to its central locati on bordering Downtown New Bedford and proximity
to dense residenti al development including adjacent multi -unit residenti al
buildings, the intersecti on is heavily traveled by vehicular traﬃ
Navigati ng this busy intersecti on in a vehicle or on foot can be confusing,
frustrati ng, and dangerous. Following 3 pedestrian crashes over the past several
years, with one crash resulti ng in a fatality, the city of New Bedford requested
that SRPEDD study the intersecti on to identi fy issues and recommend possible
The Octopus intersecti on consists of six disti nct streets with four separate
approaches, as shown in Figure 1. The immediate area consists of three high
rise housing complexes, New Bedford’s main fi re stati on, the District Court and
the city’s main U.S. Post Oﬃ
ce. The intersecti on experiences heavy vehicle and

text.i: to this locati on as the

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: The intersecti on provides important connecti ons from downtown New Bedford
to Fairhaven and Dartmouth via Route 6, as well as to the north and south ends
of the city via Pleasant Street. An oﬀ ramp from the southbound JFK Highway
(Route 18) directly connects into the intersecti on.
The intersecti on is bordered by three high rise apartment complexes. Melville
Towers, as shown in Figure 2 , contains 320 apartments with residency restricted
to seniors and people with disabiliti es. The Regency, pictured in Figure 3,
is a private high rise with 129 luxury apartments. The New Bedford Hotel
Apartments, pictured in Figure 4, also serves senior residents with a total of 112
Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
Businesses surrounding the intersecti on include various professional services,
a Walgreen’s pharmacy on the northeast corner with the main fi re stati on for
the city immediately north of the pharmacy. In additi on, there are several public
buildings, retail stores, restaurants, banks, and other faciliti es located within
walking distance of the intersecti on. Public bus service is provided throughout
the city from the main bus terminal for the Southeastern Regional Transit
Authority (SRTA), with seven of the thirteen city bus routes traveling through the
intersecti on. Additi onal desti nati ons in the downtown area include City Hall and
the New Bedford Free Public Library. Figure 1 also displays the surrounding land
use in relati on to the Octopus intersecti on.

text.i: Existi ng Conditi ons - Intersecti on Layout

page.text: The detailed informati on regarding each street for this intersecti on is as follows:
Route 6 - The westbound approach to the intersecti on is signed as U.S. Route
Bridge. As Route 6 approaches the intersecti on, an oﬀ ramp from Route 18
(the JFK Highway) merges with this segment approximately 215 feet east of the
intersecti on. The approach to the intersecti on is divided into three lanes; one
right-turn lane, one center thru lane and one left -turn lane. The center thru lane
was formerly striped as a shared thru/left -turn lane and is sti ll used as such by
many motorists who became accustomed to this designati on.
The right-turn lane is 11 feet wide, the center thru lane is 13 feet wide and the
left -turn lane is 10.5 feet wide. Total aft ernoon peak hour traﬃ
approach is 660 vehicles. The speed limit approaching the intersecti on is 30
miles per hour (mph). Route 6 is functi onally classifi ed as an Urban Principal
Arterial and is part of the Nati onal Highway System (NHS). There is a pedestrian
overpass above this approach which connects the Melville Towers property
to Pleasant Street, ulti mately providing access to Downtown. This overpass is
owned by the city. Initi ally it was the responsibility of the New Bedford Housing
Authority and is now under the purview of the New Bedford Redevelopment
Pleasant Street Southbound - The southbound approach to the intersecti on
is designated as Pleasant Street and carries two-way traﬃ
approach is divided into two lanes; a shared thru/right-turn lane and a shared
thru/left -turn lane. The thru/left lane is 14.5 feet wide while the thru/right lane
is 14 feet wide. Total aft ernoon peak hour traﬃ
c volume at this approach is 397
vehicles. Pleasant Street is functi onally classifi ed as an Urban Minor Arterial.
Pleasant Street Northbound - The northbound approach to the intersecti on is
also named Pleasant Street and carries one-way traﬃ
intersecti on. The northbound approach is divided into four lanes; a left -turn
lane, two thru center lanes and a right-turn lane with an exclusive right-turn bay
that allows free fl ow movements controlled by a yield sign. The right turn lane
(prior to the right-turn bay) is 17.5 feet wide, both thru lanes are 13 feet wide
and the left -turn lane is 11 feet wide. Total aft ernoon peak hour traﬃ
at this approach is 615 vehicles, with 118 of them turning right onto Route 6.
Pleasant Street is functi onally classifi ed as an Urban Minor Arterial.
Sixth Street - Sixth Street carries one-way traﬃ
intersecti on. It consists of two travel lanes, each approximately 20 feet wide and
it carries a total of 699 vehicles during the aft ernoon peak hour. Sixth Street is

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: functi onally classifi ed as an Urban Minor Arterial.
Kempton Street – This is designated as a one-way street eastbound towards the
intersecti on. The approach is divided into two lanes; a left -turn lane and a thru
lane. Right turns are accommodated at this approach by a right-turn slip ramp
290 feet prior to Sixth Street. The left -turn lane is 12.5 feet wide while the thru
lane is 18 feet wide. Total aft ernoon peak hour traﬃ
is 441 vehicles, with an additi onal 97 vehicles making a right-turn prior to the
intersecti on in order to access Sixth Street. The posted speed limit on this
approach is 25 mph. Kempton Street is functi onally classifi ed as an Urban Minor
Mill Street - Mill Street carries one-way traﬃ
c in the westbound directi on away
from the intersecti on. It consists of two 15 foot lanes and has a posted speed
limit of 25 mph. Total aft ernoon peak hour traﬃ
is 351 vehicles. Mill Street is functi onally classifi ed as an Urban Minor Arterial.
Together, Kempton Street and Mill Street are part of the Nati onal Highway
System and are both designated as U.S. Route 6.
Figure 5 illustrates lane widths and aft ernoon peak hour traﬃ

text.i: Lane Widths and Aft ernoon Peak Hour Traﬃ

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
In preparati on for the study, SRPEDD initi ated a broad public outreach eﬀ ort
announcing the study and held a public outreach meeti ng at the New Bedford
Free Public Library on February 1, 2012. This provided an opportunity for
residents and businesses to comment on and discuss various issues concerning
the intersecti on. SRPEDD also held a separate meeti ng at Melville Towers
to discuss the concerns of the residents regarding the intersecti on and the
pedestrian overpass directly connected to this complex.
As a result of the two meeti ngs, staﬀ identi fi ed several issues to investi gate as
part of the study. These issues are summarized into the following fi ve major
1. The pedestrian bridge is not ‘user-friendly’ and is not frequently used.
cient lighti ng, vagrants and homeless persons
loitering beneath the bridge and that it is too steep to navigate safely.
2. The green arrow for right turns at the traﬃ
confuses both pedestrians and motorists on who has the right-of-way. While
the southbound Pleasant Street approach is green, the green arrow for Route
6 westbound right turns is also acti vated. There is a “No Turn on Red” sign for
the westbound Route 6 right turns. Motorists are accustomed to making the
right turn with the green arrow. Unfortunately, motorists conti nue to make this
parti cular turn when the green arrow is deacti vated. When this occurs, they are
violati ng the “No Turn on Red” prohibiti on. This creates confusion for drivers and
pedestrians resulti ng in a potenti ally dangerous situati on as was the case where
a pedestrian was nearly run over by a heavy multi -axle truck making the right
3. A lack of a police presence to enforce motor vehicle laws exists at this
locati on, especially with the Route 6 westbound approach and motorists
ignoring the “No Turn on Red” prohibiti on.
4. The pedestrian light cycle phase at the intersecti on is not suﬃ
allow pedestrians to safely cross the street. This issue is amplifi ed for elderly or
5. A surprising revelati on at these meeti ngs was the number of people that
admitt ed to regularly walking through this intersecti on without using the

text.i: c Flow / Congesti on / Signal Operati on

page.text: The signal system at the intersecti on is a fully actuated system that uti lizes
detectors with the phases dependent on the number of vehicles waiti ng.
Unfortunately, the detectors used at this intersecti on are pole-mounted
microwave devices that are inaccurate during inclement weather. The signal
system has four separate phases, one for each approach, allowing for protected
left -turns on each phase. The fi rst phase is the Pleasant Street northbound
approach that allows all movements (right-turns, left -turns and thru movements)
to proceed. The second phase is the Pleasant Street southbound approach
which allows all movements to proceed while allowing right-turns from Route

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: 6 westbound to proceed with a green turn arrow indicati on. The third phase is
the Kempton Street eastbound approach that allows all movements (left -turns
and thrus) to proceed. The fourth phase is the Route 6 westbound approach
that allows right, left and thru movements to proceed. There is also an “all-
pedestrian” phase in the system that stops all vehicular traﬃ
phase is initi ated between the southbound and eastbound phases only when it
is acti vated by one of the pedestrian push-butt ons. Figure 6 illustrates the signal

text.i: Existi ng Conditi ons - Intersecti on Operati on

page.text: Due to constructi on on the JFK Highway at both Elm Street and Union Street
that would adversely aﬀ ect traﬃ
c volumes at the Octopus during typical traﬃ
patt erns for the downtown, analysis resulti ng from counts recorded during this
constructi on period would be suspect. Therefore, 2008-2009 volumes taken
immediately before the constructi on began were used.
c counts performed at the intersecti on revealed that it experiences
signifi cant congesti on, parti cularly during the aft ernoon or PM peak hour
period. The peak hour is when the volume of traﬃ
c is at its greatest, usually
during commuti ng ti mes. To determine the extent of the congesti on or how
ciently the intersecti on operates, the Level of Service (LOS) is calculated. LOS
is an A to F grading system that describes the amount of congesti on present at
an intersecti on based on the average delays experienced by motorists. LOS A
represents minimal delay while LOS E and F represent gridlocked conditi ons.
A count performed in 2008 revealed that the AM Peak Hour total volume was
2,187 vehicles. The AM Peak Hour was an overall LOS D with an average delay
per vehicle of 47 seconds. A count performed in 2009 revealed that the PM
Peak Hour total volume was 2,113 vehicles with an overall LOS E with a delay of
62 seconds per vehicle. Though the AM peak hour has more vehicular volume,
it operates at a bett er level of service due to less pedestrian calls and diﬀ erent
During the PM peak hour, the Kempton Street eastbound and Route 6
westbound approaches were the most congested, operati ng at LOS E. The Route
6 left -turn movement operated at the worst conditi on (LOS F). The Pleasant
Street northbound and southbound approaches operated at LOS D. Due to its
additi onal ti me allowed by the right-turn green arrow during the southbound
phase, the Route 6 westbound right-turns were the only uncongested
movement, operati ng at LOS C.

text.i: during the aft ernoon or PM

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
The Route 6 westbound approach has two unique problems. The fi rst is when
the New Bedford-Fairhaven Bridge closes to vehicular traﬃ
egress to the harbor for the fi shing fl eet and sea shipping north of the New
Bedford/Fairhaven Bridge. This bridge closure frequently causes long traﬃ
queues to build up on both sides of the swing-span bridge. When the bridge
re-opens, the sudden surge of vehicles worsens normal delays on the Route 6
westbound approach to the intersecti on. The second problem is with the Route
18 southbound ramp to Route 6 westbound which is only 215 feet from the
intersecti on, resulti ng in a dangerous and diﬃ
the intersecti on. Additi onally, some motorists traveling from the bridge and
wishing to cross three lanes to take a right onto Pleasant Street have created
their own travel lane across the grassy unpaved island prior to the intersecti on.
During the PM Peak Hour, 204 vehicles use this ramp with 13% turning right
at the intersecti on, 19% proceeding straight through the intersecti on and 68%
turning left at the intersecti on. Those vehicles wishing to turn left must cross
two lanes to do so under the intersecti on’s current confi gurati on. Figure 7
illustrates the distributi on of traﬃ
c coming oﬀ of the Route 18 southbound

text.i: Route 18 Southbound Ramp Distributi on at the Octopus
Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: The Pleasant Street southbound approach also suﬀ ers from its own unique
issues related to access and egress to the main fi re stati on located north of
the intersecti on. Currently, there is no emergency traﬃ
stati on’s driveway. Fire and emergency vehicles oft en have diﬃ
the stati on during emergencies with traﬃ
intersecti on and the Hillman Street intersecti on blocking the driveway. To
resolve this situati on, the city is installing emergency vehicle preempti on
equipment (Opti com) as part of the traﬃ
c signal at the Octopus. This will
allow emergency responders to change the signal phasing at the intersecti on in
c queues to exit the stati on and receive a green signal when

text.i: Existi ng Conditi ons - Safety Issues

page.text: A number of safety issues have been identi fi ed at this intersecti on using motor
vehicle crash reports obtained from the New Bedford Police Department. There
were 32 crashes during the three-year analysis period (2009 – 2011), including
2 pedestrian crashes. One additi onal pedestrian crash in 2008 was considered
as part of the analysis due to the high volume of pedestrian acti vity and safety
issues at the intersecti on, bringing the total to three pedestrian crashes. All of
the crash reports were reviewed to determine the specifi c circumstances of
each crash, to identi fy reoccurring trends and to develop measures to address
During the analysis period there was one fatality, 9 injury and 22 property
damage crashes. Twenty-eight percent (28%) of the crashes occurred in the
vicinity of the JFK Highway oﬀ -ramp; eighteen percent (18%) of the crash reports
contained documentati on alluding to distracted driving; and twelve percent
(12%) were att ributed to poor weather conditi ons.
Two methods are used to determine the ranking of intersecti ons in terms
of safety. The fi rst measures crash severity while the other measures crash
Equivalent Property Damage Only (EPDO) index ranks intersecti ons based on
the severity of collisions, giving greater importance to those crashes in which
injuries or fataliti es have occurred. The higher the EPDO index, the greater the
severity of the crashes. The EPDO for this intersecti on was calculated at 25.66,
exceeding the SRPEDD regional threshold of 17.7.
Accidents per Million Entering Vehicles (ACC/MEV) rate is a ranking system
c volume and measures crash probability. This system allows
a comparison of intersecti ons with diﬀ erent traﬃ
providing the probability of being in a collision at a given intersecti on. The
ACC/MEV crash rate for this intersecti on was calculated at 1.18 which exceeds
the crash threshold of 0.77 identi fi ed by the Massachusett s Department of
Transportati on (MassDOT) Highway Division. The crash data and analysis
confi rms that the intersecti on is a safety problem.
c from the New Bedford/Fairhaven Bridge and the
JFK Highway (southbound) approach experienced over half of the crashes. This
segment is heavily used by pedestrians as it provides direct access between
downtown and Melville Towers including the Walgreen’s pharmacy located on
Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
the northeast corner. Two of the three pedestrian crashes involved pedestrians
crossing this leg of the intersecti on. The fi rst of these crashes involved a motorist
driving in a westbound approach to the intersecti on. The second involved
a motorist taking a southbound left -turn from Pleasant Street to the Route
6 eastbound directi on. The remaining pedestrian crash involved a motorist
traveling westbound on Route 6 before att empti ng a right-turn onto Pleasant
Street and striking a pedestrian that was crossing the southbound leg of the
intersecti on. Figure 8 illustrates the pedestrian crashes.
There are three lanes leading to the Route 6 westbound approach. The left lane
is a left -turn only lane and the right lane is a right-turn only lane. The center lane
was, at one ti me, marked as both a left -turn and thru lane, but was changed
and the lane markings re-painted to a thru lane only. Motorists conti nue to use
the center lane as a left -turn lane due to its previous designati on and due to
the high number of left turns taken here. A total of 6 crashes (18%) involved
two westbound vehicles traveling in parallel lanes. Four of these involved
motorists in the left -turn lane att empti ng to make a thru movement colliding
with motorists in the center lane att empti ng to turn left . Based on the current
lane confi gurati ons and pavement markings all motorists were in violati on of

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: appropriate lane use. The additi onal two crashes involved motorists in parallel
lanes making a left turn and failing to yield. Figure 9 illustrates all crashes

text.i: Existi ng Conditi ons - Bicycle and Pedestrian Accommodati ons

page.text: The intersecti on in its current confi gurati on has limited bicycle accommodati ons.
There are no formal bicycle lanes through the intersecti on, however, the Mill
Street, Kempton Street and Sixth Street legs of the intersecti on have ample lane
widths that could be reconfi gured to accommodate bicycles as a shoulder or a
formal bicycle lane. The Mill Street constructi on project west of the intersecti on
is being designed with bicycle lanes, but this intersecti on is beyond the limits
of that project. Route 6 from this intersecti on to the New Bedford-Fairhaven
Bridge has a bicycle and pedestrian prohibiti on forcing bicyclists and pedestrians
to seek a diﬀ erent route to access the bridge.
Although extensive pedestrian accommodati ons exist at the intersecti on, much
of these accommodati ons are fl awed or do not meet current ADA guidelines.
Each approach has crosswalks and a pedestrian signal. The Pleasant Street
northbound approach also has a crosswalk across the right-turn bay leading to
the Route 6 Bridge. There is an exclusive pedestrian phase as part of the signal
operati on that stops all traﬃ
c to allow pedestrians to cross any approach when
acti vated by a pedestrian. Each sidewalk also includes curb ramps and marked
crosswalks. In additi on to these accommodati ons at the intersecti on, there is
a pedestrian bridge over Route 6 connecti ng Melville Towers to the north with
Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
the southern side of Route 6. There is an access walkway leading to the sidewalk
along Pleasant Street south of Route 6 and a series of stairs and sidewalks to
Walgreens, Pleasant Street and Melville Towers north of Route 6.
A number of pedestrian accommodati ons do not meet the Americans with
Disabiliti es Act (ADA) guidelines. This includes:
• Lack of a sidewalk on the Kempton Street approach;
• The crosswalk at the westbound approach is technically in the traveled
way of Pleasant Street. If it were moved east, the cobblestone median
would need to be cut back so as to not interfere with the crosswalk;
• There are no detectable warning panels at any curb cut;
• There are inappropriate apex curb cuts on the southeast and northeast
• The pedestrian signals are not Accessible Pedestrian Signals (they do not
provide informati on in non-visual ways);
ti mers in the pedestrian signals are displayed during
the walk phase. These ti mers should begin in the clearance phase as
explained in the Manual on Uniform Traﬃ
ti mes for each pedestrian signal are inadequate for slow
walkers or the mobility impaired. Currently, there is a 10-second walk
phase and a 10-second clearance phase. The MUTCD states that the
pedestrian clearance ti me should be long enough to allow a pedestrian
leaving the curb during the walk phase adequate ti me to reach the far-
side of the traveled way at 3.5 feet per second. Since this intersecti on
has an “all-pedestrian” or “scatt er” phase, it needs to accommodate the
longest crosswalk distance at 83.3 feet. Therefore, the clearance phase
should be 24 seconds, with 31 seconds of total pedestrian phase ti me.
To accommodate slower walkers and those in wheelchairs, a clearance
ti me of 28 seconds should be used (3 feet per second)]. Figure 10
illustrates these ti mings and crossing distances at each approach.
ti mes, pedestrians can wait up to 135 seconds (over
2 minutes) for the commencement of the pedestrian phase aft er
acti vati ng it with a push-butt on; and
Expansion joints at each end of overpass are greater than 3
Drainage grates are not compliant and have greater than ½ inch
At the public meeti ng, there were concerns voiced regarding the pedestrian
culty crossing the facility. Older residents, as well as
those with mobility issues, repeatedly stated this concern. Upon inspecti on,
staﬀ determined that the bridge was in general compliance according to
ADA guidelines with slopes and handrails on the access ramps leading up to
it, however, the arc of the bridge itself may have too steep of a grade to be
Another issue brought to light at the public meeti ng was the number
ng that they avoid using the pedestrian phase of the
intersecti on due to impati ence at the amount of ti me needed to wait for the
pedestrian signal, as well as the insuﬃ
cient ti me provided by the signal in order
to safely cross. During the data collecti on eﬀ orts and fi eld observati ons for the

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: pedestrian movements, staﬀ observed several pedestrians failing to use the
faciliti es provided at the intersecti on. This included pedestrians failing to use
crosswalks, failing to invoke the pedestrian phase of the signal, or entering the
intersecti on with total disregard to traﬃ
c fl ow. Figure 10 illustrates crossing
distances and necessary pedestrian signal ti mings.
The Southeastern Regional Transit Authority (SRTA) provides public transit for
the city of New Bedford. With the SRTA terminal a few blocks south of this
intersecti on, seven of the thirteen New Bedford bus routes travel through the
Octopus. Route 2 - Lund’s Corner and Route 4 - Ashley Boulevard travel north via
Pleasant Street. Route 6 - Shawmut-Rockdale, Route 8 - Mt. Pleasant, Route 9 -
New Bedford to Fall River and Route 10 - Dartmouth Mall, all travel west via Mill
and Kempton Street. Route 11 - Fairhaven travels east via Route 6.

text.i: Crossing Distances and Necessary Pedestrian Signal Timings

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
Route 2 – Lund’s Corner is the only route that services Melville Towers directly,
using Tower Drive as a deviati on. There is a small shelter/bench at the bott om
of an accessible ramp to the entrance at Melville on Tower Drive. Service to
Melville is limited, only deviati ng 12 ti mes per weekday and 9 ti mes on Saturday.
As stated at a public meeti ng, Melville residents using the bus as a means to
avoid walking thru the intersecti on can use two additi onal stops on Hillman
Street which are not ideally located. Hillman Street has a steep grade making
cult to navigate for the elderly and/or mobility impaired. As displayed
in Figure 11, there are no bus stops located directly within the Octopus
intersecti on. The closest bus stop is east of the Octopus on Mill Street.

text.i: SRTA Bus Routes Traveling Through the Octopus Intersecti on
Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: c volumes at the intersecti on were calculated in order to analyze
future congesti on issues and to ensure that any recommendati ons for
improvement are viable for at least 25 years. These volumes, representi ng the
year 2035, were calculated using SRPEDD’s Regional Travel Demand Forecasti ng
Model and show an overall increase of nearly 8%. The Regional Travel Demand
Forecasti ng Model looks at populati on, household and employment growth
c volumes on major roads in the region’s roadway network.
The city of New Bedford overall is expected to see moderate growth in both
employment and populati on by the year 2035. However, the city’s waterfront
to the east and southeast of the Octopus is projected to have high employment
growth as short sea shipping and other harbor development projects take shape.
Additi onally, the proposed Whale’s Tooth South Coast Rail stati on is expected
to bring both housing and employment growth to the area northwest of the
c conditi ons, operati ons at the intersecti on would
deteriorate to LOS E with an average delay of 76 seconds per vehicle in a
‘no-build scenario’ where no improvements are implemented. The Route 6
westbound left -turns would conti nue to be the most congested movement,
operati ng at LOS F with delays greater than 120 seconds per vehicle. Kempton
Street eastbound left -turns would also operate at LOS F and Kempton Street
eastbound thru movements and Pleasant Street northbound thru movements
c projected up to the year 2035, overall congesti on
will worsen, as will the issues parti cular to this intersecti on. In summary, these
Safety and congesti on problems at the Route 6 westbound approach
c from the Route 18 oﬀ ramp att empti ng to cross two lanes of
Route 6 westbound approach has a right-turn green arrow that works
in conjuncti on with a ‘No Turn On Red’ sign creati ng confusion for both
Vehicle queues on Pleasant Street between Hillman Street and the Octopus
are blocking access and egress to the city’s main fi re stati on;
Vehicle queues created by the closing of the New Bedford – Fairhaven
Bridge severely congests the intersecti on and contributes to the blocked
access and egress of the fi re stati on;
Pedestrian crashes including a fatality identi fi ed the poor placement of
crosswalks, inadequate crossing ti mes and an extended wait period for the
People reluctant to use the pedestrian overpass due to its isolated locati on
away from the intersecti on, its steep grade over Route 6, and concern for
personal safety when crossing the bridge alone at night.
Several diﬀ erent improvement scenarios were analyzed in an att empt to
decrease congesti on and improve both vehicular and pedestrian safety at the
intersecti on. Alternati ve A proposes to opti mize signal ti mings and update
pavement markings. Alternati ve B includes the alternati ve A improvements
coupled with the closing of the Route 18 southbound to Route 6 westbound
ramp that connects into the intersecti on. Alternati ve C investi gates the
feasibility of replacing the intersecti on with a roundabout.

text.i: will the issues parti cular to

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District

text.b: Alternati ve A: Opti mize Signal Timings and Update Pavement Markings

page.text: This alternati ve would opti mize the signal ti mings, which would require an
upgrade or the replacement of the signal system as well as updated pavement
markings at the intersecti on. Updated pavement markings would include re-
striping the center lane on the Route 6 westbound approach as a shared thru/
left -turn lane with line extensions conti nuing through the intersecti on and onto
Sixth Street. These markings help guide vehicles through the intersecti on and
prevent sideswipe crashes. A lane use sign depicti ng this new confi gurati on at
the westbound approach would also be helpful in giving motorists advanced
warning of the proper lane use. Figure 12 displays MUTCD sign number R3-8a.
Pavement markings on Pleasant Street north of the intersecti on and on Sixth
street south of the intersecti on are also needed in order to formalize two travel
lanes on each of these legs and bett er guide traﬃ
This alternati ve would also change the exclusive pedestrian phase to separate
concurrent phases that would operate in conjuncti on with each non-opposing
signal phase. Adequate pedestrian crossing ti mes for each approach based on
its crossing width would also be necessary. Figure 13 illustrates the potenti al
concurrent pedestrian phasing at this intersecti on.
As shown in Figure 13 photo A, the pedestrian att empti ng to cross the Route
6 westbound approach would see a ‘Walk’ symbol when the Pleasant Street
northbound approach vehicles have a green signal. In photo B the Kempton
Street eastbound vehicles have a green signal while pedestrians crossing Sixth
Street or the Pleasant Street northbound approach would see the ‘Walk’ signal.
A similar patt ern exists for the Route 6 westbound phase and the Pleasant Street

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: southbound phase as shown in photos C and D respecti vely. Table 1 displays the
necessary pedestrian signal ti mes in seconds for each approach.
c conditi ons, this alternati ve would improve intersecti on
ciency from an LOS E to an LOS D and would lower the average delay from 62
seconds to 49 seconds per vehicle. The Kempton Street eastbound and Route
6 westbound approaches would also be improved from LOS E to LOS D. Under
c conditi ons, overall intersecti on Level of Service would remain an LOS
E, however, the average delay would decrease from 76 seconds to 56 seconds per
vehicle. The Route 6 westbound left -turn would improve from LOS F to LOS E.

text.b: Alternati ve B: Close the Route 18 Southbound Ramp to Route 6 Westbound

page.text: Closing this ramp would alleviate the dangerous weave patt ern that takes place
on the Route 6 westbound approach to the intersecti on while eliminati ng 204
vehicles from the westbound approach during the PM peak hour. Under existi ng
c conditi ons with opti mized signal ti mings and concurrent pedestrian phases,
this would improve the westbound approach from a LOS E to a LOS C and would
reduce delay from 76 seconds per vehicle to 34 seconds per vehicle. Overall
intersecti on operati on would improve from LOS E to LOS D, with delay being
reduced from 62 seconds per vehicle to 47 seconds per vehicle.
c conditi ons under this scenario were analyzed using a TransModeler
simulati on for the surrounding area for the year 2035. With these improvements,
overall intersecti on operati on would improve from LOS E to LOS D, reducing delay
from 76 seconds per vehicle to 50 seconds per vehicle. The Route 6 westbound
approach would improve from a LOS F to a LOS D, reducing delay from 107
seconds per vehicle to 38 seconds per vehicle.
The 204 vehicles that used the Route 18 southbound ramp to Route 6 westbound
during the PM peak hour would likely relocate to other exits to the downtown
area from Route 18. This includes the Purchase Street ramp or the Elm Street and
Union Street intersecti ons. SRPEDD’s Regional Travel Demand Forecasti ng Model
esti mates that 40% of the ramp traﬃ
c would use the Purchase Street exit, 45%
would use the Elm Street intersecti on and 15% would conti nue to Union Street.
Figure 14 illustrates the redistributi on of traﬃ
c resulti ng from the closure of this
c diverted to the Purchase Street ramp would re-enter the
intersecti on at the Pleasant Street southbound approach (approximately 57
c at the Purchase Street oﬀ -ramp would deteriorate
the operati on of that intersecti on and likely necessitate a traﬃ
18 southbound ramp to Purchase Street is currently under stop sign control
with a fl ashing red light for the ramp approach and a fl ashing yellow light for the
Purchase Street approaches. The ramp is 27’ wide approaching Purchase Street
and has two un-marked lanes for both right and left turns. The ramp approach

currently operates at LOS F during the PM peak hour with an average delay
of 60 seconds per vehicle. This delay may be slightly exaggerated, given the

c from the Route 18 southbound ramp to Route
6 westbound (approximately 82 vehicles), the Purchase Street ramp delay
would increase further, exceeding 120 seconds per vehicle. The installati on
c signal would improve the ramp’s operati on to LOS A under during
c conditi ons. Table 2 summarizes existi ng and
future conditi ons at the Octopus intersecti on under a no-build scenario and

text.i: PM Peak Hour Intersecti on Level of Service and Average Delay per
Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: A roundabout at this locati on was considered as a measure to improve
both congesti on and safety. Under current traﬃ
would necessitate two lanes at the southbound, eastbound and westbound
approaches. According to the Federal Highway Administrati on’s (FHWA)
guidance on roundabouts, if the sum of the approach volume and the circulati ng
volume is between 1,200 and 2,000 vehicles per hour then a two lane approach
could functi on properly . Sums less than 1,200 vehicles per hour could functi on
properly with a single lane approach. Table 3 below summarizes approach
volumes and circulati ng volumes for this intersecti on if a roundabout were
constructed. As is evident from the table, only the northbound approach could
functi on properly with a single lane approach.
MassDOT has guidance on the roundabout sizes necessary to accommodate
certain vehicles according to roadway functi onal classifi cati on. Since this
intersecti on consists of arterial roadways, a circle with a minimum of 100 feet in
diameter would be necessary as shown in Figure 15. Given that this intersecti on
would need to be a multi -lane roundabout, an additi onal 50 to 100 feet is
necessary to accommodate the extra lanes. A circle 150 to 200 feet in diameter
would infringe on the parkland between Sixth Street and Pleasant Street.

text.i: PM Peak Hour Approach Volumes and Circulati ng Volumes at a Potenti al Roundabout
*Exceeds single-lane roundabout 1,200 vph threshold for proper func

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
Multi -lane roundabouts tend to be confusing to motorists and diﬃ
to navigate (parti cularly those with disabiliti es). In additi on, land-takings would be
necessary to fi t a multi -lane roundabout at this locati on. Therefore, a roundabout is not
Regardless of the improvement alternati ves, there is also a need for additi onal
pedestrian educati on to inform residents in the immediate area as well as throughout
the city on the safe and proper way to cross busy intersecti ons. This includes the
distributi on of informati on signs and brochures targeti ng the populati on who frequently
use the Octopus including the surrounding high rise apartments and residences
surrounding the intersecti on. SRPEDD can provide this informati on and with the
assistance and cooperati on of the city and residenti al area, distribute this informati on to
bett er inform the public on how to traverse this intersecti on properly and safely.
This alternati ve will opti mize signal ti mings, and provide a concurrent pedestrian signal
phasing. It would require an upgrade or the replacement of the existi ng traﬃ
equipment. It also includes updati ng pavement markings and signage, including re-
striping the Route 6 westbound center lane to accommodate a shared thru/ left -turn
movement. It would also include some geometric modifi cati ons to accommodate all
improvements. The concurrent pedestrian signal phases and pedestrian educati on are an
integral component to improve mobility and safety for pedestrians at this intersecti on.
Other issues not directly within the intersecti on including the defi ciencies of the
pedestrian overpass, lighti ng and overgrown shrubbery in the surrounding areas, need
to be addressed by the city of New Bedford.
Other pedestrian and bicycle safety improvements under this alternati ve include:
Constructi on of a sidewalk along the southern side of Kempton Street leading up
The installati on of longitudinal crosswalks at all approaches and across the
northbound right-turn bay with ADA-compliant curb ramps and detectable
The inclusion of proper pedestrian signage at each crossing, including pedestrian
signal explanatory signs (R-10-3i) shown in Figure 16 and “turning vehicles yield
Installati on of a “no right-turn” sign (R3-1) at the eastbound approach;
Installati on of a yield sign and yield pavement markings at the approach to the
crosswalk across the northbound right-turn bay;
Reducti on of the median at the westbound approach so it does not interfere
with the crosswalk and the re-striping of the crosswalk further east so it is not in
the traveled way of the intersecti on;
Constructi ng two curb-ramps at both the northeast and southeast corners of the
intersecti on to eliminate the inappropriate apex curb ramps that exist on these
Installati on of Accessible Pedestrian Signals that enable audible push-butt on
locators and audible walk/don’t walk phases to work with the concurrent
Clearing and maintenance of overgrown brush on the northeast corner of the
intersecti on to maximize sight distance of both vehicles and pedestrians;

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: “T-oﬀ ” the right-turn slip ramp from Kempton Street to Sixth Street to slow
Tighten the northbound right-turn lane and bay on Pleasant Street to slow down
Pedestrian educati on, specifi cally for the residents of the surrounding high-rise
apartments, in the necessary and proper use of pedestrian accommodati on;
Formal bicycle lanes on Kempton Street, Mill Street and Sixth Street;
Bicycle detectors at all four approaches to the intersecti on; and
A multi -use path from the southeast corner of the Octopus paralleling Route
6 to the JFK Highway to connect to the JFK Highway Bike Path currently under

under Alternati ve A. Of parti cular importance are the new signage recommendati ons,
cial sign number in the MUTCD.

page.text: Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
To bett er illustrate the new signage and pavement markings from a motorist’s perspecti ve, Figures 18 through 21, on the
following pages, depict each approach (westbound, eastbound, southbound and northbound) with a rendering of these

text.i: Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: This is a long-term considerati on that does not provide much additi onal benefi t to the intersecti on and surrounding area
in order to justi fy its higher cost. A traﬃ
c signal at the Purchase Street/Route 18 oﬀ -ramp along with the proper signage
on Route 18 would be vital to this scenario functi oning properly.
Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District
Table 4 summarizes existi ng and future conditi ons at the intersecti on under a
no-build scenario (no improvements) and improvement alternati ves A and B.
As illustrated in Table 4 above, Alternati ves A and B result in the same Level
of Service in 2012 with only a few seconds of diﬀ erence in delay per vehicle.
Alternati ve B would require involvement by MassDOT and the Federal Highway
Administrati on (FHWA) since Route 18 and Route 6 are on the Nati onal
Highway System (NHS). Alternati ve A is much more cost-eﬀ ecti ve and could
be implemented with limited constructi on. Therefore, Alternati ve A is the
preferred recommendati on of this study.
The Octopus intersecti on is owned by the city of New Bedford and therefore, a
majority of the implementati on of improvements recommended would be the
responsibility of the city. Alternati ve A, the replacement of the existi ng signal
system, would be the responsibility of the city of New Bedford and include
the bicycle and pedestrian improvements. Alternati ve B, the closing of the
Route 18 ramp, would require input, approval and project development by the
Massachusett s Department of Transportati on (MassDOT) and FHWA since Route
18 is a state-owned highway and as with Route 6, is part of the Nati onal Highway
The intersecti on is eligible for federal funding and therefore, improvements
could be funded through the Transportati on Improvement Program (TIP) using a
Congesti on Miti gati on/Air Quality Improvement (CMAQ) Funds-for
projects that demonstrate an air quality improvement; and
Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP) – for projects that
demonstrate the potenti al for reducti on in crashes.
The city should consult SRPEDD’s Transportati on Project Funding Guide for
further guidance on funding sources and project development using the
Transportati on Improvement Program. Uti lizing TIP funds requires design
approval and project oversight by MassDOT. The city also has the opti on of
using Chapter 90 funds to implement the recommended improvements under
Alternati ve A, allowing for the greatest fl exibility of implementati on.
New Bedford needs to commit to redesign the signal system, leading to its
replacement that will address both traﬃ
c and pedestrian needs. It should be
capable of addressing occasional daily bridge openings to eﬀ ecti vely clear the

text.i: PM Peak Hour Intersecti on Expected LOS for Present and Future Conditi ons
Pleasant Street-Kempton Street-Mill Street-Sixth Street-Route 6 Intersecti on Study, New Bedford

page.text: gridlock that can occur. MassDOT and both New Bedford and Fairhaven should
prioriti ze the eventual replacement of the Bridge with a more eﬃ
span to minimize the frequent and oft en excessive delays that hinder traﬃ
fl ow into and out of the Central Business District, as well as emergency vehicles
The City should also ensure that vehicle preempti on equipment, such as
Opti com, is included in the signal system to accommodate the nearby fi re
stati on. The city should also plan to regularly maintain pavement markings
following installati on so they remain prominent. The city should also begin to
address the issues with the pedestrian overpass to make it more user friendly.
In preparati on for the study, SRPEDD initi ated a broad public outreach eﬀ ort. Transportati on staﬀ went door to door
in the downtown area distributi ng fl yers announcing the study and a public outreach meeti ng. This provided an
opportunity for staﬀ to speak with residents and businesses to encourage att endance at the public outreach meeti ng.
Flyers were also mailed to all abutt er’s of the intersecti on and SRPEDD delivered fl yers to all residents of the Regency, the
New Bedford Hotel Apartments and Melville Towers. A press release was circulated and appeared in the New Bedford
Standard-Times on January 20, 2012. Staﬀ were also interviewed by radio stati on WBSM on January 25, 2012, with
subsequent airings leading up to the public meeti ng. Following the meeti ng, a second newspaper arti cle appeared in the
New Bedford Standard Times highlighti ng the issues discussed at the meeti ng.
The public meeti ng held at the New Bedford Free Public Library on February 1, 2012 included extensive comments
and discussion from several residents on the many issues encounter at the intersecti on. SRPEDD conducted a separate
meeti ng at Melville Towers to hear the concerns from the residents because the complex connects directly to the
pedestrian overpass. In additi on, two of the 3 pedestrian crashes at the intersecti on, discussed later in this report,
As a result of the two meeti ngs, staﬀ identi fi ed several issues to investi gate while conducti ng the study of the
intersecti on. This includes frequent users of the intersecti on expressing identi cal complaints and concerns on driving
and/or walking through the intersecti on. These common complaints are summarized into the following fi ve major
1 The pedestrian bridge is not ‘user-friendly’ with many residents citi ng this concern as to why it is not uti lized
more. Contributi ng factors to the low use include insuﬃ
cient lighti ng, vagrants and homeless persons loitering
beneath the bridge and that it is too steep to navigate safely.
2 The green arrow for right turns at the traﬃ
c signal for Route 6 westbound confuses pedestrians and motorist on
who has the right-of-way. While the southbound Pleasant Street approach is green, the green arrow for Route 6
westbound right turns is also acti vated. There is a “No Turn on Red” sign for the westbound Route 6 right turns.
Motorists are accustomed to making the right turn with the green arrow. Unfortunately, motorists conti nue
to make this parti cular turn when the green arrow is deacti vated. When this occurs, they are violati ng the “No
Turn on Red” prohibiti on. This creates confusion for drivers and pedestrians resulti ng in a potenti ally dangerous
situati on. In one instance, a pedestrian was nearly run over and killed by a heavy multi -axle truck making the
3 A lack of a police presence to enforce motor vehicle laws exists at this locati on. Increased police enforcement
is needed, especially in relati on to the violati on at the Route 6 westbound approach and motorists ignoring the
4 The pedestrian light cycle at the intersecti on is not adequate to allow pedestrians to safely cross the street.
Numerous residents complained about this parti cular signal ti ming. This issue is amplifi ed for elderly or mobility
5 A surprising revelati on at these meeti ngs was the number of people that admitt ed to regularly walking through
this intersecti on without using the pedestrian signal. This indicated that in additi on to any modifi cati ons to
the signal system, pedestrian educati on especially for the residents of the surrounding high-rises should be
considered as part of the miti gati on.
